in.labulle.anycode.uml

Interface IRelationAttribute

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IAttribute, IElement

    public interface IRelationAttribute
extends IAttribute
    UML relationship attribute. It is class attribute that is linked to another classifier of the model. One particularity of this UML API is that relationships themselves are not part of the model, i.e. : there is no 'Relationship' class. This choice is made on purpose as it enables to describe any relationship and it is easier for code generation, because a class has all its attributes, regardless they are simple or relational attributes.
    Author:
    Jose Carreno

    • Method Detail

      • isNavigable

        boolean isNavigable()
        attributes navigability. An attribute that is not navigable should not be explicitely part of the classifier.
        Returns:
        true if attribute is navigable or if navigation is not specified, false otherwise.

      • isComposition

        boolean isComposition()
        Checks whether this relationship side is a composition.
        Returns:
        true if this relation side is a composition

      • isAggregation

        boolean isAggregation()
        Checks whether this relationship side is a aggregation.
        Returns:
        true if this relationship side is a aggregation

      • isManyToOne

        boolean isManyToOne()
        Checks if attribute is 'many to one'. i.e. : this side is associated to zero or one element of the other side type and the other side is associated with several elements of this side type. One example : a [Person] has several [Car]s, a [Car] belongs to zero or one [Person], which is modelled with 'owner' attribute in [Car] class. Then owner relation attribute isManyToOne.
        Returns:
        true if the relation attribute is many-to-one.

      • isOneToOne

        boolean isOneToOne()
        Checks if attribute is 'many to one'. i.e. : this side is associated to zero or one element of the other side type and the other side is also associated with zero or one element of this side type. One example : a [User] has zero or one [UserAccount], a [UserAccount] belongs to one [User], which is modelled with 'user' attribute in [UserAccount] class. Then use relationship attribute isOneToOne.
        Returns:
        true if the relationship attribute is one-to-one.

      • isManyToMany

        boolean isManyToMany()
        Checks if attribute is 'many to many'. i.e. : this side is associated to several elements of the other side type and the other side is associated with several elements of this side type. One example : a [Student] attends [Course]s, a [Course] can be attended by several [Student]s, which is modelled with 'courses' attribute in [Student] class. Then courses relationship attribute isManyToMany.
        Returns:
        true if the relationship attribute is many-to-many.

      • isOneToMany

        boolean isOneToMany()
        Checks if attribute is 'one to many'. i.e. : this side is associated to several elements of the other side type and the other side is associated with zero or one element of this side type. One example : a [Person] has several [Car]s, a [Car] belongs to zero or one [Person], which is modelled with 'cars' attribute in [Person] class. Then cars relationship attribute isOneToMany.
        Returns:
        true if the relationship attribute is one-to-many.

      • getOtherSide

        IRelationAttribute getOtherSide()
        Gets the other side relationship attribute. Together, both attributes enables to have the necessary information about the UML relation itself.
        Returns:
        relationship attribute. Cannot be null.

      • isOwningSide

        boolean isOwningSide()
        Checks where this attribute is the owning side of this relationship. This concept of owning side is common in ORM mappings. The owning side is the side that ORM tool will use to persist changes. As a consequence, unidirectional relationship attribute will always be the owning side (as it will not be part of the other side class). Now here are some rules about owning side in bidirectional relationships :
        • A bidirectional relationship has both an owning side and an inverse side.
        • A unidirectional relationship only has an owning side.
        • ORM tool will (generally) only check the owning side of an association for changes.
        Returns:
        true if this attribute is the owning side.

      • isBidirectionalRelation

        boolean isBidirectionalRelation()
        Checks if this 'relationship' is bidirectional. If it is not, it doesn't mean that this side is the owning side (it can be an unidirectional relationship owned by the other side).
        Returns:
        true if relationship is bidirectional.
